Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will partially support the 2019 Field of Dreams Conference, to be held at the Renaissance St. Louis Airport Hotel, in St. Louis, MO, November 15-17, 2019. The Field of Dreams Conference is organized by the Math Alliance, an organization whose goal is to increase the number of students from backgrounds underrepresented in the mathematical sciences who earn doctorates in those fields. Approximately 200 undergraduate and terminal MS students will attend the conference, and about 75% of those will be underrepresented minorities. All funds from this award will be used to pay the cost of attendance for some of these students. The conference coordinates with the Math Alliance's Facilitated Graduate Admissions Process (F-GAP), which has helped place an average of about 80 Math Alliance Scholars per year in graduate programs the last six years with very good retention to this point. The conference is an essential part of a program to produce a more diverse professional mathematical workforce. In addition, there are events at the conference which assist faculty in mentoring practices and help academic departments transform their cultures to be more inclusive and supportive of student success.

The Field of Dreams conference has several purposes, including: providing information about all aspects of the mathematical sciences professions to students wishing to pursue doctoral studies; providing information about summer research programs and opportunities at the NSF-funded Mathematical Sciences Institutes; facilitating appropriate placement of Math Alliance students in graduate programs; providing professional development in mentoring and cultural competence for our Math Alliance faculty; and serving as a clearinghouse for employment opportunities for new (and recent) Math Alliance doctoral recipients. More information about the Math Alliance is available at www.mathalliance.org. Material from previous years' conferences, are available at https://mathalliance.org/field-of-dreams-conference/, and the page for the 2019 conference is https://mathalliance.org/2019-field-of-dreams-conference/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 Field of Dreams Conference was held November 14-17, 2019, at the Renaissance Airport Hotel in St. Louis, MO. Washington University in St. Louis was the host institution, and provided major support. Further support was provided by Purdue University, Penn State University, University of Minnesota, National Security Agency, the American Statistical Society, Purdue University's Krannert School of Management, and the American Mathematical Society, in addition to the support of NSF through the award being reported on here. Further support was provided by the Center for the National Math Sciences Alliance, in the Purdue University College of Science. Four Universities are Partners in the Center, and over 30 Mathematical Science Departments are members of the Center, supporting the work of the Alliance in general. There were 365 registered conference participants: 154 undergraduate and terminal MS Alliance Scholars, 152 faculty mentors, 45 Ph.D. students, and 14 participants were exhibitors, representatives of NSF Funded Math Science Institutes, Alliance Board members and Staff, and outside speakers.

The Field of Dreams Conference is a major activity of the Alliance. It is an important part of the F-GAP program, which is designed to place current seniors and terminal MS students in graduate programs in the mathematical sciences. We have seen a steadily increasing number of F-GAP students entering graduate programs each year, and at least 88 such students entered graduate programs in fall of 2019, following their participation in the 2018 Field of Dreams Conference. Since 2014, we know of 530 F-GAP students who have entered graduate programs. We also know of over 141 underrepresented minority students currently enrolled in Alliance Graduate Program Groups (this includes some F-GAP students, of course), and we believe, based on AMS data, this represents at least 20% of all underrepresented minority students in mathematical science graduate programs. Alliance Predoctoral Scholars have received at least 119 doctorates since our inception in 2007 (this does not include those Ph.D.s produced by the precursor "Alliance for the Production of African American Ph.D.s in the Mathematical Sciences"). Considering the time to Ph.D. these are largely concentrated in the last six years. This represents a significant impact on the professional mathematical workforce.

The Graduate Fair gives graduate programs, REUs, and mathematical science institutes, access to about 150 undergraduate students, about 70-80% of them underrepresented minority students. These students have been recommended by an undergraduate faculty mentor as being well prepared for graduate programs. This can only help programs diversify their pool of applicants. We hope to see the demographics of the profession transform as we continue this work.

Major Conference Activities included:

  • Connections Lecture (S. James Gates, Brown University);
  • Mathematical Sciences Lecture (David Hummels, Purdue University);
  • Keynote Address (Roselyn Williams, Florida A&M University);
  • Fields of Success Panel (Math Alliance Doctorates tell their stories);
  • Career Fair;
  • Graduate Fair;
  • REU Fair;
  • Professional development panels;
  • Grad school preparation and success panels;
  • Community building.
